summary_visit.AdmissionSummary: A 65-year-old female with a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia was admitted on 09/22/2024 for an acute myocardial infarction after presenting to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left arm, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. On admission, her vitals showed a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg, heart rate of 110 bpm, respiratory rate of 20 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Troponin levels were significantly elevated at 2.0 ng/mL, and the ECG showed sinus tachycardia without ST-segment changes. Initial management included admission to the cardiac ICU, continuous ECG monitoring, and cardiac enzyme monitoring. Medications started included aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, benzazepril, atorvastatin, and apixaban. A stress ulcer prophylaxis regimen with pantoprazole was added the following day. The patient remained stable, but on 09/24/2024, she developed symptoms of a urinary tract infection, which was managed with empiric antibiotic therapy (ciprofloxacin). By 09/26/2024, the patient reported no chest pain or shortness of breath and was clinically stable.

medications.name: Aspirin
medications.reason: Secondary prevention of myocardial infarction (antiplatelet therapy)

medications.name: Clopidogrel
medications.reason: Secondary prevention of myocardial infarction (antiplatelet therapy)

medications.name: Metoprolol
medications.reason: Rate control in atrial fibrillation and management of hypertension

medications.name: Ciprofloxacin
medications.reason: Empiric antibiotic therapy for urinary tract infection

notes.note_content:
Date: 09/22/2024

Author: Michael Davis, MD

Subjective:

  • CC: Chest pain, shortness of breath
  • HPI: A 65-year-old presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The chest pain started 2 hours ago and is described as pressure-like, radiating to the left arm. The patient also reports shortness of breath and diaphoresis.

Objective:

  • Vitals: BP 140/90, HR 110, RR 20, T 98.6, O2 Sat 95% on RA
  • Physical Exam: Chest: Clear to auscultation, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops, no JVD
  • Labs: Troponin: 2.0 ng/mL, CK-MB: 20 U/L, BNP: 100 pg/mL
  • ECG: Sinus tachycardia, no ST-segment changes

Assessment:

  • Acute myocardial infarction (MI)
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia

Plan:

  • Admit to the cardiac ICU
  • Medications: Aspirin 81 mg daily, Clopidogrel 75 mg daily, Metoprolol 25 mg BID, Benzazepril 10 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg daily, Apixaban 5 mg BID
  • Procedures: Continuous ECG monitoring, Cardiac enzyme monitoring
  • Consult cardiology

Date: 09/23/2024

Author: Sarah Lee, MD

Subjective: Patient condition: Unstable, requiring intensive care.

Objective:

  • Vitals: [As above]
  • Physical Exam: [As above]
  • Labs: [As above]
  • ECG: [As above]

Assessment:

  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Hemodynamic instability

Plan:

  • Medications: Continue medications from admission note, Add Pantoprazole 40 mg daily for stress ulcer prophylaxis
  • Procedures: Continuous ECG monitoring, Invasive hemodynamic monitoring (if needed), Consider PCI or CABG

Date: 09/24/2024

Author: Sarah Lee, MD

Subjective: Symptoms: Dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain.

Objective:

  • Urine Analysis: Leukocyte esterase positive, nitrite positive, bacteria present
  • Urine Culture: Pending

Assessment:

  • Urinary tract infection

Plan:

  • Medications: Start empiric antibiotic therapy (Ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily) pending culture results

Date: 09/26/2024

Author: John Baxter, MD

Subjective: Patient reports mild fatigue but no chest pain or shortness of breath.

Objective:

  • Vitals: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 80 bpm, RR 18, T 98.6°F, O2 Sat 98% on room air
  • Physical Exam: Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Respiratory: Clear lung sounds bilaterally. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Extremities: No edema.

Assessment:

  • Stable post-MI
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • UTI, resolving

Plan:

  • Continue current medication regimen
  • Monitor for any new symptoms or complications
  • Schedule cardiology follow-up

Date: 09/27/2024

Author: John Baxter, MD

Subjective: Patient reports feeling improved and less fatigued.

Objective:

  • Vitals: BP 118/78 mmHg, HR 75 bpm, RR 18, T 98.2°F, O2 Sat 98% on room air
  • Physical Exam: Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Respiratory: Clear lung sounds bilaterally. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Extremities: No edema.

Assessment:

  • Continued improvement post-MI
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia

Plan:

  • Continue current medication regimen
  • Educate patient on importance of medication adherence, lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise), and symptom monitoring
  • Discharge planning initiated

medication_orders.name: Metoprolol
medication_orders.indication: Rate control in atrial fibrillation and management of hypertension

medication_orders.name: Pantoprazole
recommendation_notes: Patient showing decreased symptoms of GERD.
No significant acid reflux observed over the last 3 months.
